I think we need a proper cross platform solution for this. Currently it looks more like a hack that fixes the issue for Windows-only. X11 and macOS has the same issue. Instead of updating QGuiApplicationPrivate::mouse_buttons directly from platforms plugin we need to extend QWindowSystemInterface::handle{Drag,Drop} to include mouse/keyboard button state. This way all plugins will be enforced to do the right thing. Otherwise how can a plugin writer be aware of this internal Qt Gui detail (from qguiapplication):

QPlatformDragQtResponse QGuiApplicationPrivate::processDrag
QDragMoveEvent me(p, supportedActions, dropData,
                      QGuiApplication::mouseButtons(), QGuiApplication::keyboardModifiers());

QPlatformDropQtResponse QGuiApplicationPrivate::processDrop
    QDropEvent de(p, supportedActions, dropData,
                  QGuiApplication::mouseButtons(), QGuiApplication::keyboardModifiers());

Also updating ::mouse_buttons like this is really not what the documentation states:

"Returns the current state of the buttons on the mouse. The current state is updated syncronously as the event queue is emptied of events that will spontaneously change the mouse state (QEvent::MouseButtonPress and QEvent::MouseButtonRelease events)."

According to my understanding the only place that should be allowed to change the value of ::mouse_buttons is QGuiApplicationPrivate::processMouseEvent.

QGuiApplication::mouseButtons() in general is not a very useful API. I am currently looking into https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTBUG-33161 that is why I ended up on this gerrit change :)

The issue with other platforms is that QGuiApplication::mouseButtons does not contain the current mouse button state when drag operation originates from a non-Qt process.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

-1 because of no autotest (there's already one which can be adapted).

In general, I think the problem you're trying to fix (please correct me if I got this wrong) is the emission of selectionChanged/currentChanged with old and new indices belonging to different models.

IMHO this should be expected and documented. This allows a user listening to those virtuals to correctly track what the selection is at any given point in time, and the virtual calls are always consistent.

In other words, calling IS a set of indexes, given a series IS[0] ... IS[N] of N+1 of consecutive selections applied to the view, then the view will call selectionChanged N  times carrying the pairs IS[i], IS[i+1]. This will be done even if for some k IS[k] and IS[k+1] belong to different models.

(Mutatis mutandis for the current index)

On the other hand, with this patch, the series of will be 

..., (IS[k-1], IS[k]), (QModelIndex(), IS[k+1]), ...

conceptually (again, IMHO) breaking the semantics of a changed method which carries old and new values, which nows sees a new "wild" value.


Now the problem I *do* see is that my semantics are not actually expected from Qt own views, and there are bugs lingering there. For instance,

https://code.woboq.org/qt5/qtbase/src/widgets/itemviews/qabstractitemview.cpp.html#3614

expects "previous" to be an index handed out by d->model (wrong!) and that a row comparison is possible against current (wrong if they belong to different models!). OTOH, this very patch will also break the update logic, as handling out an invalid previous index won't cause an update for its visual region, leading to visual glitches.

Patch Set 6:

> I'm hesitant about adding more code-paths for testing event delivery. Let's chat about this in the office tomorrow?

This has immediate benefits, see e.g:

https://codereview.qt-project.org/#/c/209925/
https://codereview.qt-project.org/#/c/208017/

Mouse handling has been somewhat ignored for a long time, instead of fixing things properly we have been "stabilizing this or that test and then few weeks later blacklisting the same tests because they are unstable") and this patch actually makes things work.

And all these QTest::mouse* APIs can coexist. This coexistence works better in dev branch as that is where https://codereview.qt-project.org/#/c/193415/ and related patches went in. Actually in dev branch these API work completely independently. In 5.10 and below, each subsequent test function uses mouse_buttons in whatever state it was left by the test functions that run earlier (deducing incorrect mouse event types). So adding this code-path won't make the broken functionality of "mouse button deduction worse" in 5.10 and below. It is already broken. Using QTestPrivate::mouse*() overloads has several benefits - see the commit message.

The option of fixing QTest::mouse() directly would result in behavior changes, which would brake not only our tests, but also for everyone else who uses that qtestlib API:

- not all passed in widgets would return valid window in "widget->window()->windowHandle()".
- refactoring case MouseMove: QCursor::setPos(widget->mapToGlobal(pos)); to wait for pos to change could result in unexpected side effects for users.
- replacing "!qApp->notify(widget, &me)" with proper QWindowSystemInterface API could result in unexpected side effects for users.

Also this code path will go away, once we are done porting our tests. Simple grep command can replace all QTestPrivate::mouse* with QTest::mouse* when the time comes.

Patch Set 6:

@Thiago/all - I'm not familiar with this code, so I will let BogDan speak to the implementation.  I can speak to our need for it in Qt Remote Objects, though, which is why we asked KDAB to look at this enhancement.  We use Q_GADGETs for sending structs in signals/slots, or as property values.  However, we hit an issue when we try to use them dynamically on the receiving side: since the metaobject system of a separate device or process doesn't know about the type, it can't decipher it.

We need a way to dynamically register Q_GADGETs.  But there isn't a single constructor we can point to (without additional information) that can construct the right properties for a Q_GADGET that is defined at runtime.  By passing the type to the constructor, we have additional information, so the static/single constructor can lookup the given types properties.  Again, see the QtRO change (https://codereview.qt-project.org/#/c/237450) for an example of usage.

Put another way, this change allows us to have a single constructor that supports a class of types (Q_GADGET, specifically), by providing the type to the constructor.

For Q_GADGET, we don't need a typed destructor.  I'm not sure if there are other use-cases that might, I think that is a great question.

Game changer: The regexp() is not called concurrently if SQLite is not used concurrently (https://www.mail-archive.com/sqlite-users@mailinglists.sqlite.org/msg100498.html). So we do not have to protect the cached QRegularExpressions since we use SQLite only from the thread that has opened the connection (http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/threads-modules.html#threads-and-the-sql-module).

The static function _q_regexp, however, can be called from different threads which luckily is no problem as it only uses local members and arguments. sqlite3_context is further "connection" aware so that two QSqlDatabases created and opened in the same thread used two different caches (user data).

It's enough that std::string(const char*) is implicit, which is one of the reasons why I advise everyone not to use direct initialisation with single-argument constructors: http://marcmutz.wordpress.com/2010/08/24/a-case-against-direct-initialisation-%E2%80%94-the-sequel/

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

The difference between Qt4 and Qt5, is as follows. In Qt4, QApplication implemented a virtual public commitData() method (the sole point at which a commitDataRequest() signal is emitted). KApplication (subclassed from QApplication) then overrides commitData() and does not use the commitDataRequest() signal. The default Qt4 commitData() does attempt to close all app windows (just as in Qt5), but again, KApplication overrides this behavior and so the issue is not present in Qt4 (at least for KApps).

In Qt5, QApplication subclasses QGuiApplication which does not provide an overridable commitData() method, implementing it instead as the private QGuiApplicationPrivate::commitData(), where, as in Qt4, this is the sole point at which a commitDataRequest() signal is emitted. In KF5 we use QGuiApplication for apps and therefore always implicitly use QGuiApplicationPrivate::commitData() and respond to the commitDataRequest() signal emitted from it. The problem then with QGuiApplication as it is now, is that, regardless of what an app does in a slot connected to commitDataRequest(), QGuiApplicationPrivate::commitData() will always attempt to close all app windows immediately after the commitDataRequest() signal processing. Furthermore, even if a KMainWindow-based app does not act on the commitDataRequest() signal, but rather, uses the overridable queryClose() provided by KMainWindow, if window closure is accepted, windows will still be closed prematurely, ie, before the window manager does its session saving.

So, to summarize, it appears to me that both the Qt4 and Qt5 default behavior of closing windows on session shutdown is undesirable (as noted, the issue doesn't occur in KDE4 because the behavior was overridded). To me, then, in Qt5 it seems to be more appropriate to imploy the commitDataRequest() signal without any associated window closures and let the session manager itself do this.

In regards to this set of patches, then, while it is surely a possible strategy to fix the problem, it seems to be overkill/overly-complicated. Instead, quite some time ago, I proposed simply removing the window closures from QGuiApplicationPrivate::commitData() (see https://codereview.qt-project.org/#/c/140115), and fixing session management in KF5 as required (see https://bugs.kde.org/show_bug.cgi?id=346768, and the associated patches, https://bugs.kde.org/attachment.cgi?id=95380 and https://bugs.kde.org/attachment.cgi?id=95381.

Patch Set 1:

I looked into the siblingIndex and I don't believe we can use it. The siblingIndex of all the items in a scene is not unique. Imagine a scene that has three top level items (A, B, and C) and that item C has three children (X, Y, and Z). If the items were inserted in that order, the siblingIndex of these items is A=0, B=1, C=2, X=0, Y=1, Z=2. This is what's ensured by QGraphicsItemPrivate::ensureSequentialSiblingIndex(). If I now delete item B, I cannot use its siblingIndex value to correctly update the linear index, since B and Y have the same siblingIndex. The linear index requires an index that is unique for each item in the scene, and in the presence of hierarchies, siblingIndex is not unique. The code you wrote for removeItem() and addItem() is valid for scenes with top-level items only. Not to mention that there are methods that update the siblingIndex of an item, so we'll need to also adjust these to somehow notify the linear index about the changes. I don't see a working solution there.

In general the problem with using a free indices approach is that there is no way to quickly get the indices. A search over the list is slow and any other approach would require extra memory that maps an item to an index.

Since you asked, here is some info about my application: It has a single top-level item that contains all the other items in a deep, fairly well distributed hierarchy. Every single item fully contains its children in its bounding rectangle. Initially I used the default BSP index, but once I started playing with a big number of items, that index became a huge bottleneck. It is really slow to create and maintain. Take the chips demo for example, on my machine it takes a few seconds to start it when using the BSP index, whereas with the linear index, it is instant. And this is just 40 000 items, with millions the slowdown is unacceptable. Moreover I really don't need the BSP index, as my items fully contain their children, the default indexer implementation is very efficient. Regarding memory consumption, the 58MB are irrelevant for my application, since with so many items it already consumes 1.71 GB of ram. In case you're interested, the application is an early prototype of a visual IDE which I'm developing for my PhD, you can checkout some videos here: http://dimitar-asenov.github.io/Envision/

Patch Set 7:

My argument is like this:
* the OS does not support environment variables. If you don't like it, please use http://connect.microsoft.com to voice your displeasure.
* more importantly, that means we cannot get environment variables set from the outside. That means the only variables that are ever set in our environment are those as a result of qputenv.
* qputenv will not affect child processes as there's no way to communicate that information to them, nor will it affect non-Qt code as it will have no access to our fake environment. Quite a few unit tests that use qputenv expect this to work, which it cannot ever work. Therefore, if we ever want those tests to pass on WinCE/RT, they will need to be fixed by other means.

There are only two cases of qputenv in library code that gets compiled to CE/RT:
* qtmain_winrt.cpp, with result of __getmainargs (see https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff770599.aspx). Since there is no external environment on WinRT, this is probably dead code and can be safely removed.
* qtestcase.cpp, setting QT_LOGGING_TO_CONSOLE=1 and QT_QTESTLIB_RUNNING=1. The latter is only used on OS X and presumably would be used by child processes. Clearly that wouldn't work.

That leaves only one valid use of qputenv: to control our own library features from unit tests. To accommmodate that, I think it's best to move the fake environment code to qglobal.cpp and remove the wrapper functions that exist in qfunctions_win{ce,rt}.h, as https://codereview.qt-project.org/143423 does.

The only remaining question is whether we provide it always or whether we provide it only in developer-build mode.

I would propose for developer build mode only. I don't think it's Qt's business to provide this functionality when the platform vendor thought people didn't need it. The vendor specifically and intentionally removed support for a function mandated by ISO C. No matter what we do, we cannot emulate it properly because of the lack of external communication.

No, it is hopeless, in practice we have given up on getting things working sanely out of the box on all RPi distros out there since you never know which graphics stacks a particular distro is shipping and what the libEGL/GLESv2 we want is called.

We also need to take care of some level of background compatibility since customers won't jump to newer versions just because somebody decides to rename libEGL again, or introduces an unusable alternative graphics stack.

You probably won't be surprised to hear that the upstream blob repo (https://github.com/raspberrypi/firmware) recently changed the approach *again*, this time going for a side-by-side approach where the Broadcom stack is called libbrcmEGL, libbrcmGLESv2, etc. with no telling what libEGL/libGLESv2 (if those are symlinks even) and the pkg-config entries point to. (and no idea how and where the Mesa binaries would be shipped and what that would be called)

Distros and distro building tools (Yocto) are free to modify this of course, some may not have /opt/vc/lib at all, etc.

One fine day it will all be simple, once Mesa's RPi support matures and it becomes the primary graphics stack, and we can forget about the Broadcom stack. Then RPi distros won't be any different from a usual desktop distro in this respect. Until then I suggest not to spend valuable time on this mess.

(one exception is the RPi3 image in QtDC - we must ensure that keeps building)
